meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>rich</kanji> so the verb vocab version would be <vocabulary>to be rich in</vocabulary>.

富む is a formal word that's commonly used in writing. While it can refer to material wealth, it's more commonly used figuratively to describe an abundance of a certain quality, a place rich in nature or specific resources, or emotional richness or fulfillment.
reading_mnemonic: Think about the richest person you know. That person is <reading>Tom</reading> (とむ). Imagine Tom as being super rich. If you don't know a Tom, think of a famous Tom, like Tom Cruise, who definitely is pretty rich.

examples.en: In the past, I wanted to gain both fame and wealth, but now all I want to gain is wealth.
examples.ja: 昔は名声も富も得たいと思っていましたが、今得たいのは富だけですね。

examples.en: It is not just money that brings wealth. True wealth is something felt when the heart becomes rich.
examples.ja: 富をもたらすのは、お金だけじゃないよ。真の富は、心が豊かになることで感じるものだからね。

examples.en: Making a fortune of millions is not as easy as I thought.
examples.ja: 巨万の富を築くことは思ったより簡単ではありません。

examples.en: They say that 90% of the world's wealth is actually in the possession of a small group of powerful people who make up the Cult of the Crabigator.
examples.ja: 世界の富の９割は、実はクラビゲーター教団を構成する少数の権力者たちが持っていると言われている。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are almost exactly the same. Someone who is <kanji>rich</kanji> has <vocabulary>wealth</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>riches</vocabulary>, right?
reading_mnemonic: For the reading, think about the person you know with the most <vocabulary>wealth</vocabulary>. It is <reading>Tommy</reading> (とみ) Hilfiger.

examples.en: The Maldives is a highly popular resort destination among the wealthy class.
examples.ja: モルディブは富裕層の間で人気の高いリゾート地です。

examples.en: Coming from a wealthy family, you wouldn't understand.
examples.ja: 富裕な家庭出身のあなたには分からないでしょうね。

examples.en: I heard that WaniKani has elite club-like content accessible only to a small number of wealthy individuals. Is that true?
examples.ja: ワニカニには少数の富裕者だけがアクセスできるエリートクラブ的なコンテンツがあると聞いたのですが、本当ですか？

examples.en: Why do we separate people into the rich and the poor?
examples.ja: どうして人は富裕層と貧困層に分けられるのでしょうか。

meaning_mnemonic: If you're <kanji>rich</kanji> and <kanji>abundant</kanji>, you are super <vocabulary>wealthy</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>affluent</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>rich</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: There are moral education classes at school.
examples.ja: 学校では道徳の授業があります。

examples.en: The movie taught children the importance of morality.
examples.ja: その映画は、子供たちに道徳の大切さを教えました。

examples.en: As we grow up, we may have fewer chances to think about morality.
examples.ja: 大人になると、道徳について考える機会は少なくなるかもしれない。

examples.en: Why are you so sure that animals have no sense of morality?
examples.ja: どうして動物には道徳感がないって断言できるの？

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>way</kanji> of <kanji>virtue</kanji> is the way you take if you have <vocabulary>morals</vocabulary>. Hopefully you have some.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Who is Ieyasu Tokugawa?
examples.ja: 徳川家康って誰？

examples.en: Doesn't my dog kind of look like someone from the Tokugawa family?
examples.ja: うちの犬、徳川家っぽい顔してると思わない？

examples.en: I said I wanted to go back to the Tokugawa era — Mom took my phone.
examples.ja: 徳川の時代にもどりたいって言ったら、ママにスマホ取り上げられた。

examples.en: She likes Japanese history and is very familiar with the Tokugawa Shogunate.
examples.ja: 彼女は歴女で、徳川幕府にはとても精通しています。

meaning_mnemonic: This is one of those words that makes more sense when you look at the reading. The "Virtue River" isn't some virtuous river, it's in fact the <vocabulary>Tokugawa</vocabulary> family name, made famous by the Tokugawa shogunate. They ran Japan for a while, you know?
reading_mnemonic: The readings are 徳 and the vocab 川 put together into one word. Once you can read this, you'll know the meaning too, so focus on the reading for this one. Just watch out for the rendaku that changes かわ to がわ!

examples.en: I haven't been to Tokushima yet, but I'd love to visit someday.
examples.ja: 徳島県にはまだ行ったことがないけど、いつか行ってみたいんだよね。

examples.en: I picked up a tourism pamphlet for Tokushima at the station.
examples.ja: 徳島県の観光パンフレットを駅でもらいました。

examples.en: I was surprised that Tokushima was more urban than I expected.
examples.ja: 徳島県、思ったより都会でびっくりした。

examples.en: Governor, in what ways would you change Tokushima Prefecture? I think I like things just the way they are.
examples.ja: 知事は、徳島県をどういう風に変えていくおつもりですか？私は今のままがいいと思うのですが。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>virtue</kanji> <kanji>island</kanji> <kanji>prefecture</kanji> is <vocabulary>Tokushima prefecture</vocabulary>. The reading will give away the meaning of this one, so long as you knew "prefecture."
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the individual kanji. Put them together and you'll know this is <vocabulary>Tokushima Prefecture</vocabulary>.

examples.en: I'll help you look for your contact lens!
examples.ja: コンタクト、探すの手伝うよ！

examples.en: I looked online for a cheap hotel.
examples.ja: ネットで安いホテルを探してみた。

examples.en: I looked for the remote for ten minutes. It was in the toaster.
examples.ja: 10分探したリモコン、トースターの中にあった。

examples.en: A three legged dog walked into a bar and said, "I'm searching for the man who shot my paw. He looks like half fugu and half tofu."
examples.ja: 三本足の犬がバーにやって来てこう言った。「俺の足を撃った男を探しているんだ。半分河豚で半分豆腐みたいな男なんだが。」

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>look for</kanji> and the verb version of the kanji is <vocabulary>to look for</vocabulary>.


Curious about the difference between 捜す and 探す? While there is some overlap between the two, 捜す is typically used in official, thorough searches for something or someone that is thought to concretely exist and has disappeared or cannot be easily found. In contrast, 探す can also be used for personal searches for things that one desires or is looking for.
reading_mnemonic: You are looking for a <reading>sagger</reading> (さが) amongst the products you're shipping off overseas. The saggers are the boxes that have weird lumps sagging out of them, which means they broke and are getting things wet. So, find the saggers. Go <vocabulary>to search for</vocabulary> them, because they could ruin the whole shipment.

examples.en: Continuing to have an inquisitive mind is the key to growth.
examples.ja: 探究心を持ち続けることが、成長のカギです。

examples.en: WaniKani was created through researching how to learn kanji and vocabulary efficiently.
examples.ja: どうすれば効率よく漢字やボキャブラリーが習得できるのかを探究して出来上がったのがワニカニです。

examples.en: Only through inquiry can we discover new possibilities and perspectives.
examples.ja: 探究を通じてのみ、私たちは新しい可能性と視点を発見することができるんです。

examples.en: This book documents my research into religion, that is, a record of the search for truth.
examples.ja: 本書は私の宗教の探究、すなわち真理の探究の記録である。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Look for</kanji> something. <kanji>Research</kanji> answers. This is an <vocabulary>academic inquiry</vocabulary>, or in other words, <vocabulary>research</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Maybe you've been watching detective dramas a bit too much?
examples.ja: 探偵ドラマの見すぎじゃない？

examples.en: She ended up becoming a private detective.
examples.ja: 彼女は結局探偵になりました。

examples.en: My grandpa says, "I used to be a detective," but I wonder if it's true.
examples.ja: おじいちゃんが「オレは昔、探偵だった」って言ってるんだけど、本当かなぁ？

examples.en: Our dog loves playing detective. He's always sniffing shoes. It's so cute, isn't it?
examples.ja: うちの犬、探偵ごっこが大好きなんです。ずっとクツをクンクンかいじゃって、かわいいですよね。

meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>look for</kanji> things and you <kanji>spy</kanji> on people. Your job isn't as glamorous as it sounds. You're a <vocabulary>private detective</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: When do the police conduct their secret internal investigation?
examples.ja: 警察はどんな時に内偵捜査をするのですか。

examples.en: I heard that restaurant was secretly investigated by the tax office.
examples.ja: あのレストラン、税務署の内偵調査が入ったらしいよ。

examples.en: I asked a detective agency to secretly investigate my husband's affair.
examples.ja: 探偵事務所に夫の浮気の内偵調査をお願いしました。

examples.en: I heard the Kyoto Prefectural Police have started a covert investigation.
examples.ja: 京都府警が内偵を開始したらしいよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you go <kanji>inside</kanji> somewhere to quietly <kanji>spy</kanji> on someone, you're doing a <vocabulary>secret investigation</vocabulary>.

内偵 is a formal word for investigations where the target doesn't know they're being investigated. It can mean an <vocabulary>undercover investigation</vocabulary> by police, or it can be a secret check on a business partner, a new hire, or even a suspicious spouse by companies or detectives.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: You can't move forward if you always fear failure.
examples.ja: 失敗を恐れてばかりいては前に進めないよ。

examples.en: I'm not afraid of anything except for going blind.
examples.ja: 目が見えなくなること以外は、何も恐れることはないよ。

examples.en: We should not fear change and should continue to challenge ourselves with new things.
examples.ja: 私たちは変化を恐れずに、どんどん新しいことにチャレンジしていくべきです。

examples.en: Koichi fears his own power.
examples.ja: コウイチは自分の力を恐れているんですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>fear</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to fear</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is shared with 恐ろしい, which is "scary." Use that, and don't be afraid. You'll be able to learn this reading yet.

examples.en: Sorry, I didn't mean to lead you astray…
examples.ja: ごめん、迷わすつもりじゃなかったんだけど…。

examples.en: You should avoid saying things that mislead others.
examples.ja: 相手を迷わすような発言はしないようにすべきだ。

examples.en: They deliberately put up false signs to lead people astray.
examples.ja: 人々を迷わすために、あえて間違った看板が立てられているんだよ。

examples.en: If you lead my daughter astray, I'll never forgive you.
examples.ja: もし俺の娘を路頭に迷わすようなことがあったら、一生許さないぞ。

meaning_mnemonic:
You learned 迷う means "to go astray," and 迷わす is its transitive version, meaning it takes a direct object. So it means <vocabulary>to lead someone astray</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to perplex someone</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to mislead someone</vocabulary>.

While 迷わす can mean literally causing someone to get lost, it's more commonly used for the act of confusing someone — for example, overwhelming them with difficult choices or intentionally misleading them in a malicious way.

You know this verb is transitive because there's nothing <reading>worse</reading> (わす) than purposefully misleading someone. Intentionally leading someone astray is worse than anything!
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 迷う, so use that so you aren't lead astray too.

examples.en: It will take a little time to load the luggage, so wait there!
examples.ja: 荷物を積むのに少し時間がかかるから、そこで待ってて！

examples.en: He steadily and diligently accumulated experience and earned his current position.
examples.ja: アイツは地道にコツコツ経験を積んで、今の地位を手に入れたんだよ。

examples.en: Now please grab a partner and begin loading the truck with turkey.
examples.ja: それじゃあ2人組を作って、トラックに七面鳥を積み始めて下さい。

examples.en: His "to-be-read" list had many books piled up.
examples.ja: 彼の積ん読リストには、たくさんの本が積まれていた。

meaning_mnemonic:
You learned that 積もる (to accumulate) is used when something like snow or dust piles up over time. 積む is the transitive version, so it means <vocabulary>to pile something up</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to stack up</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to load</vocabulary>. You know this because you are the one <reading>mo</reading>ving (む) things to pile them up!

積む is often used for physical actions like stacking boxes or loading luggage, but it's also used in more abstract ways, such as building up experience or skills. Think of it like "stacking up" experience points to level up in your life!
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 積もる, so pile up your knowledge and remember it that way.

examples.en: This event is hosted by the city.
examples.ja: このイベントは市が主催するものです。

examples.en: Our school is hosting a karaoke party this Saturday. Would you like to join us?
examples.ja: うちの学校で土曜日にカラオケパーティーを主催するんだけど、よかったら来ない？

examples.en: How many users do you think would join if WaniKani hosted a kanji boot camp?
examples.ja: ワニカニが漢字合宿を主催したら、参加してくれるユーザーさんはどれくらいいると思いますか？

examples.en: Some elderly ladies in the neighborhood hosted a bingo tournament, and the first prize was gold dentures.
examples.ja: 近所のおばあちゃんたちがビンゴ大会を主催してくれたんだけど、一位の景品は金の入れ歯でした。

meaning_mnemonic:
If 主催 means "host" or "hosting," the verb version of that would be <vocabulary>to host</vocabulary>.

主催する refers to hosting events, especially formal ones like conferences, concerts, or company parties. It's not just about "doing" an event — it shows that the person or group is the main sponsor and organizer, the one really in charge of making it happen.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 主催 already as well.

examples.en: I can't forget the face of the gorilla urging for a banana.
examples.ja: バナナを催促するゴリラの顔が忘れられない。

examples.en: I pressed my sister for a reply on LINE, and she just sent a sticker.
examples.ja: 妹にLINEの返事を催促したら、スタンプだけ返ってきた。

examples.en: My girlfriend pushed me to propose… I'm not ready.
examples.ja: 彼女にプロポーズを催促された。まだ心の準備が…

examples.en: I'm sorry to be so demanding, but can you take some pictures of Tokyo Tower and send them to me by Monday please? Thanks.
examples.ja: 催促するようで申し訳ありませんが、東京タワーの写真を何枚か撮って月曜日までに送ってもらえませんでしょうか。

meaning_mnemonic: If 催促 is <kanji>urge</kanji>, then the verb version would be <vocabulary>to urge</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know 催促 first.

examples.en: Even though he failed many times, he didn't give up.
examples.ja: 彼は、幾度失敗しても、諦めなかった。

examples.en: Countless times, humanity has repeated the same mistakes.
examples.ja: 幾度も幾度も人類は同じ間違いをくり返してきた。

examples.en: I keep recalling your fragile smile from that moment, and I deeply reflect on the fleeting and beautiful nature of existence.
examples.ja: その時の君のか細い笑顔を幾度となく思い出しては、僕は存在というもののはかなさと美しさについて、深く考える。

examples.en: It feels as though I've walked the same path countless times. And that path always seemed to lead somewhere distant, yet it continued toward the same landscape.
examples.ja: 幾度となく同じ道を歩んできたように思える。そして、その道は、いつも遠くのどこか、しかしこれもまた同じ風景へと続いていた。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>How many</kanji> <kanji>occurence</kanji>s is just another way of asking <vocabulary>how many times</vocabulary>.

This word is more literary and formal than 何回 or 何度.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this.

examples.en: I think that's probably true.
examples.ja: それは恐らく本当のことだと思います。

examples.en: He probably knows about the news.
examples.ja: 彼は恐らくそのニュースを知っているはずです。

examples.en: This is probably the last chance.
examples.ja: 恐らくこれが最後のチャンスでしょう。

examples.en: The criminal is probably lurking in this area.
examples.ja: 犯人は恐らくこの辺りにひそんでいるのでしょう。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji in this word means fear, but the word itself means probably. I guess you only have to fear something if it's probably going to happen, you know?
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

examples.en: She feels a strong fear of speaking in front of others.
examples.ja: 彼女は人前で話すことに対して強い恐れを感じています。

examples.en: Feeling fear is natural, but you must not be controlled by it.
examples.ja: 恐れを感じることは自然なことですが、それに支配されてはいけません。

examples.en: His fear ultimately became the driving force for him.
examples.ja: 彼の恐れは、最終的に彼を動かす力となった。

examples.en: There is a risk of a landslide.
examples.ja: 土砂崩れの恐れがあります。

meaning_mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>fear</kanji>, so it means <vocabulary>fear</vocabulary> too.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

examples.en: Will you work as my bodyguard?
examples.ja: 私の用心棒をしてくれない？

examples.en: He works as a bodyguard.
examples.ja: 彼は用心棒として働いている。

examples.en: I can walk safely because there's a bodyguard.
examples.ja: 用心棒がいるから、安心して歩ける。

examples.en: Her bodyguard is always right behind her.
examples.ja: 彼女の用心棒は、いつも彼女の後ろにぴったりくっついている。

meaning_mnemonic:
"<kanji>Use</kanji> your <kanji>heart</kanji> and this <kanji>pole</kanji> when you guard me," you tell your <vocabulary>bodyguard</vocabulary>. A good bodyguard needs both — the heart of a lion, and a nice sturdy pole to smack fools with.

用心 actually means "caution," so 用心棒 suggests someone who watches out for danger — often with a 棒 (stick) in hand! The word has a bit of an old-school, samurai-era feel, but it still gets used both in writing and conversation from time to time.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Flower arrangement is a part of traditional Japanese culture.
examples.ja: 華道は日本の伝統文化です。

examples.en: I started attending a Japanese flower arrangement class.
examples.ja: 華道教室に通い始めました。

examples.en: I've been learning Japanese flower arrangement since I was little.
examples.ja: 私は小さいころからずっと華道を習っています。

examples.en: The kadō teacher gazed at my work and murmured, "The flowers don't lie."
examples.ja: 華道の先生が、私の作品を見つめながら「花は正直だから」とつぶやいた。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>flower</kanji> <kanji>way</kanji> (or the way of the flower) is the Japanese art of <vocabulary>flower arrangement</vocabulary>.

With such a lofty name, you know this isn't referring to any old flower arrangement you can buy in a shop. This is for the art and practice of <vocabulary>Japanese flower arrangement</vocabulary>, also known as ikebana.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Shouldn't you restrain yourself from wearing a gaudy dress?
examples.ja: 華美なドレスはひかえた方がいいんじゃないですか。

examples.en: It's a very nice piece, with an extravagant design, but also leaves a calm impression.
examples.ja: 華美なデザインなのに、落ち着いた印象もあるとてもいい作品だね。

examples.en: Beneath the lavish chandelier, there was a single potato lying all alone.
examples.ja: 華美なシャンデリアの真下に、ジャガイモが１つだけポツンと落ちていた。

examples.en: Which prefecture is known for being a good market for used cars and for its reputation of not favoring a flashy lifestyle?
examples.ja: 中古車がよく売れる地域としても有名で、華美な生活を好まないことで知られている県は何県でしょう？

meaning_mnemonic:
If something has <kanji>showy</kanji> <kanji>beauty</kanji> then it's going a little overboard and is going to come across as <vocabulary>gaudy</vocabulary> <vocabulary>ostentation</vocabulary>. Too much is too much.

Compared to the similar word 派手 (flashy), 華美 suggests a more refined kind of <vocabulary>splendor</vocabulary> — luxurious and elegant, but a tad excessive. It's a formal word, generally used in writing to describe clothing or decor that's beautiful but verges on being showy.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Because of construction work, my usual running route has been extended.
examples.ja: 工事のせいでいつものランニングのコースが延びた。

examples.en: The Tokyo Olympics were delayed to the following year, but they might get canceled.
examples.ja: 東京オリンピックは翌年に延びたがキャンセルになるかもしれない。

examples.en: I hate it when meetings are prolonged because of my boss.
examples.ja: 上司のせいで会議が延びるのが嫌いです。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

This is an intransitive verb, meaning that it happens on its own, and we're not talking about what makes it happen. So this verb means <vocabulary>to be extended</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to be delayed</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to be prolonged</vocabulary>. If you know the word ビル, you can think about how building work is always prolonged or delayed, to help you remember that this is intransitive. We never know why it's delayed, it just happens all by itself!
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.

Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 延ばす.

examples.en: Most of the politicians in our country are men.
examples.ja: 我が国の政治家の多くは男性だ。

examples.en: In our country, mandatory vaccination of the population is under consideration.
examples.ja: 我が国では、国民のワクチン接種の義務化が検討されています。

examples.en: Currently, foreigners without resident status are not allowed to enter our country.
examples.ja: 現在、在留資格のない外国人は、我が国への入国が認められておりません。

meaning_mnemonic:
You learned that 我が means "our", so our <kanji>country</kanji> is simply <vocabulary>our country</vocabulary>.

Just like 我が itself, this expression is somewhat old-fashioned and stylized. It comes up a lot in political discourse and other formal contexts.
reading_mnemonic: You learned this reading for 我 when you learned 我が. Just watch out for 国, which you might expect to rendaku here, but doesn't!

examples.en: Is it true that many male cats are left-handed?
examples.ja: 猫の雄に左利きが多いって本当ですか？

examples.en: Apparently all the puppies that were born were male!
examples.ja: 生まれた子犬、みんな雄だったみたい！

examples.en: The male golden-backed squirrel courts by making a frog-like croaking sound.
examples.ja: タイワンリスの雄は、カエルのような鳴き声を出して求愛します。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji means male and this also means male. It's mostly used for animals.

Note that this is often written in katakana, as オス.
reading_mnemonic: <vocabulary>Male</vocabulary> animals can be kind of pushy, always trying <reading>to push</reading> (押す) other animals around, trying to be the alpha and all.

examples.en: The new employee has abundant experience.
examples.ja: 新しい社員には豊富な経験があります。

examples.en: Carrots are a rich source of beta-carotene.
examples.ja: 人参にはベータカロテンが豊富に含まれている。

examples.en: This store has a wide selection of items.
examples.ja: この店は品ぞろえが豊富です。

meaning_mnemonic: Something that's <kanji>plentiful</kanji> and <kanji>rich</kanji> is <vocabulary>abundant</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>plentiful</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>rich</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi of both kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I'm saving this money for my future self.
examples.ja: このお金は、未来の自分のために貯めるの。

examples.en: Oh, you're saving up miles for your honeymoon trip?
examples.ja: えっ、ハネムーン旅行のためにマイルを貯めてるんですか？

examples.en: Japanese people really love collecting reward points, don't they?
examples.ja: 日本人って本当にポイント貯めるのが好きだよね。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>savings</kanji>, so the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to save up</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to store</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to accumulate</vocabulary> something valuable.

貯める is used when you're saving up something useful over time — typically money, loyalty points, or airline miles, for example, but sometimes water and other resources too.
reading_mnemonic:
This word uses the kun'yomi reading for 貯, which you haven't learned yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you out:

You have <vocabulary>to save up</vocabulary> for <reading>ta</reading>cos (た). Not only are tacos more expensive these days, you also have a horrible taco addiction that you need to plan ahead and save for every month.
